metadata.titleEn: Typical debris flow events in the Yunnan Section of the main stream of Nu River (1950-2021)
metadata.description: 1) The name, location, disaster outbreak time, disaster and event records, and data sources of major debris flows with historical outbreaks in the Yunnan section of the main stream of the Nu River; 2) Based on the reference to existing literature, based on on-site surveys and remote sensing interpretation Form this data; 3) This data updates the number of historical major debris flow outbreaks in the Yunnan section of the Nujiang main stream from 86 in the original literature to 134, thus forming the latest event record in the Yunnan section of the Nujiang main stream that can clearly identify specific debris flow gullies. It provides more detailed data for the study of the distribution patterns, main controlling factors, and evolutionary trends of major debris flows in the main stream of the Nu River, and can provide data support for local government risk prevention and control.
metadata.instructions: Historical Outbreak of Major Debris Flows in the Yunnan Section of the Nujiang River (1950-2021)

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the data collection methods used to update the number of major historical debris flow events in the Nujiang River mainstream in Yunnan from 86 to 134?
Feature Specification.Answer: referencing existing literature, conducting field surveys and interviews, using remote sensing interpretation

Quantification.Question: How many significant debris flow events have been recorded along the main stream of the Nujiang River in Yunnan between 1950 and 2021?

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the key factors that have led to the increased number of recorded major debris flow events in the Nujiang River mainstream segment in Yunnan from the original 86 to 134 between 1950 and 2021?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The increase in the recorded number of major debris flow events in the Nujiang River mainstream segment in Yunnan from 86 to 134 is attributed to the application of enhanced data collection methods, including referencing existing literature, conducting field surveys and interviews, and utilizing remote sensing interpretation. These methods provided more comprehensive data, allowing for the identification of specific debris flow channels and offering a more detailed record of past events.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of updating historical records of major debris flow events in the Nujiang River's Yunnan section on future research and risk prevention strategies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: By updating the historical records of major debris flow events from 86 to 134 instances, researchers gain a more comprehensive dataset that provides greater detail on the distribution patterns, controlling factors, and evolutionary trends of these events. This enhanced dataset can significantly improve the understanding of debris flow dynamics, aid in the development of more accurate predictive models, and support local governments in developing more effective risk prevention and management strategies.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the detailed steps involved in collecting and integrating historical debris flow event data along the Nujiang mainstream in Yunnan from 1950 to 2021, and how do these methods contribute to updating the event records?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection involves referencing existing literature and conducting field surveys and remote sensing interpretations. This approach updated the number of recorded major debris flow events from 86 to 134, providing more precise data on specific debris flow locations. This enhanced dataset supports research on distribution patterns, controlling factors, and evolution trends of debris flows, as well as risk prevention for local government planning.
